entries.name: Enumerable
entries.description: Enumerable is a parent structure that contains a set of suffixes common to few structures in kOS. As a user of kOS you will never handle pure instances of this structure, but rather concrete types like List, Range, Queue etc.

entries.name: ITERATOR
entries.description: for iterating over the elements

entries.name: REVERSEITERATOR
entries.description: for iterating over the elements in the reverse order

entries.name: LENGTH
entries.description: number of elements in the enumerable

entries.name: CONTAINS
entries.description: check if enumerable contains an item

entries.name: EMPTY
entries.description: check if enumerable is empty

entries.name: DUMP
entries.description: verbose dump of all contained elements

entries.name: Iterator
entries.description: An iterator can be obtained from Enumerable:ITERATOR as well as from other places. An ITERATOR is a generic computer programming concept. In the general case it’s a variable type that allows you to get the value at a position in some collection, as well as increment to the next item in the collection in order to operate on all objects in the collection one at a time. In kOS it operates on Lists and most other collection types. A loop using an Iterator on a List might look like this:

entries.name: RESET
entries.description: (This method has been removed)

entries.name: NEXT
entries.description: Move iterator to the next item

entries.name: ATEND
entries.description: Check if iterator is at the end of the list

entries.name: INDEX
entries.description: Current index starting from zero

entries.name: VALUE
entries.description: The object currently being pointed to

entries.name: Lexicon
entries.description: A Lexicon is an associative array, and is similar to the LIST type. If you are an experienced programmer who already knows what “associative array” means, you can probably skip this section and go to the next part of the page further down, otherwise read on: In a normal array, or in kerboscript’s LIST type you specify which item in the list you want by giving its integer position in the list.
entries.snippet:
set arr to lexicon().
arr:add( "ABC", 1234.1 ).
arr:add( "Carmine", 4.1 ).
print arr["ABC"]. // prints 1234.1
print arr["Carmine"]. // prints 4.1

entries.name: ADD
entries.description: append an item to the lexicon

entries.name: CASESENSITIVE
entries.description: changes the behaviour of string based keys. Which are by default case insensitive. Setting this will clear the lexicon.

entries.name: CASE
entries.description: A synonym for CASESENSITIVE

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all items in the lexicon

entries.name: COPY
entries.description: returns a (shallow) copy of the contents of the lexicon

entries.name: DUMP
entries.description: verbose dump of all contained elements

entries.name: HASKEY
entries.description: does the lexicon have a key of the given value?

entries.name: HASVALUE
entries.description: does the lexicon have a value of the given value?

entries.name: KEYS
entries.description: gives a flat List of the keys in the lexicon

entries.name: VALUES
entries.description: gives a flat List of the values in the lexicon

entries.name: LENGTH
entries.description: number of pairs in the lexicon

entries.name: REMOVE
entries.description: removes the pair with the given key

entries.name: HASSUFFIX
entries.description: True if the suffix OR a key with the name, exists.

entries.name: SUFFIXNAMES
entries.description: Gives both the suffixes AND the keys that work as suffixes

entries.name: List
entries.description: A List is a collection of any type in kOS. Many places throughout the system return variables of the List type, and you can create your own List variables as well. One of the places you are likely to find that kOS gives you a List is when you use the LIST command to list some query into one of your variables.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF ENUMERABLE
entries.description: List objects are a type of Enumerable

entries.name: ADD
entries.description: append an item

entries.name: INSERT
entries.description: insert item at index

entries.name: REMOVE
entries.description: remove item by index

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all elements

entries.name: COPY
entries.description: a new copy of this list

entries.name: SUBLIST
entries.description: new list of given length starting with index

entries.name: JOIN
entries.description: joins all list elements into a string

entries.name: FIND
entries.description: returns the first index of the item within the list

entries.name: INDEXOF
entries.description: Alias for FIND(item)

entries.name: FINDLAST
entries.description: returns the last index of the item within the list

entries.name: LASTINDEXOF
entries.description: Alias for FINDLAST(item)

entries.name: Queue
entries.description: A Queue is a collection of any type in kOS. Queues work according to First-In first-out principle. It may be useful to contrast Queue with Stack to better understand how both structures work. You can read more about queues on Wikipedia.
entries.snippet:
SET Q TO QUEUE().
Q:PUSH("alice").
Q:PUSH("bob").

PRINT Q:POP. // will print 'alice'
PRINT Q:POP. // will print 'bob'

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF ENUMERABLE
entries.description: Queue objects are a type of Enumerable

entries.name: PUSH
entries.description: add item to the end of the queue

entries.name: POP
entries.description: returns the first element in the queue and removes it

entries.name: PEEK
entries.description: returns the first element in the queue without removing it

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all elements

entries.name: COPY
entries.description: a new copy of this queue

entries.name: Range
entries.description: Range is a type that represents a sequence of scalar whole numbers. The sequence can start and finish at any whole number, can be either descending or ascending and can skip numbers.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF ENUMERABLE
entries.description: Range objects are a type of Enumerable

entries.name: START
entries.description: initial element of the range

entries.name: STOP
entries.description: range limit

entries.name: STEP
entries.description: step size

entries.name: Stack
entries.description: A Stack is a collection of any type in kOS. Stacks work according to Last-In first-out principle. It may be useful to contrast Stack with Queue to better understand how both structures work. You can read more about stacks on Wikipedia.
entries.snippet:
SET S TO STACK().
S:PUSH("alice").
S:PUSH("bob").

PRINT S:POP. // will print 'bob'
PRINT S:POP. // will print 'alice'

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF ENUMERABLE
entries.description: Stack objects are a type of Enumerable

entries.name: PUSH
entries.description: add item to the top of the stack

entries.name: POP
entries.description: returns the item on top of the stack and removes it

entries.name: PEEK
entries.description: returns the item on top of the stack without removing it

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all elements

entries.name: COPY
entries.description: a new copy of this stack

entries.name: Uniqueset
entries.description: A UniqueSet is a collection of any type in kOS. It doesn’t store items in any particular order and does not allow duplicate items. You can read more about sets on Wikipedia. Usage example:
entries.snippet:
SET S TO UNIQUESET(1,2,3).
PRINT S:LENGTH. // will print 3
S:ADD(1). // 1 was already in the set so nothing happens
PRINT S:LENGTH. // will print 3 again

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF ENUMERABLE
entries.description: UniqueSet objects are a type of Enumerable

entries.name: ADD
entries.description: append an item

entries.name: REMOVE
entries.description: remove item

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all elements

entries.name: COPY
entries.description: a new copy of this set

entries.name: Filecontent
entries.description: Represents the contents of a file. You can obtain an instance of this class using VolumeFile:READALL. Internally this class stores raw data (a byte array). It can be passed around as is, for example this will copy a file:
entries.snippet:
SET CONTENTS TO OPEN("filename"):READALL.
SET NEWFILE TO CREATE("newfile").
NEWFILE:WRITE(CONTENTS).

entries.name: LENGTH
entries.description: File length (in bytes)

entries.name: EMPTY
entries.description: True if the file is empty

entries.name: TYPE
entries.description: Type of the content

entries.name: STRING
entries.description: Contents of the file decoded using UTF-8 encoding

entries.name: BINARY
entries.description: Contents of the file as a list of bytes

entries.name: ITERATOR
entries.description: Iterates over the lines of a file

entries.name: Path
entries.description: Represents a path. Contains suffixes that can be helpful when using and manipulating paths. You can use path() to create new instances. Instances of this structure can be passed as arguments instead of ordinary, string paths, for example:
entries.snippet: copypath("../file", path()).

entries.name: VOLUME
entries.description: Volume this path belongs to

entries.name: SEGMENTS
entries.description: List of this path’s segments

entries.name: LENGTH
entries.description: Number of segments in this path

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Name of file or directory this path points to

entries.name: HASEXTENSION
entries.description: True if path contains an extension

entries.name: EXTENSION
entries.description: This path’s extension

entries.name: ROOT
entries.description: Root path of this path’s volume

entries.name: PARENT
entries.description: Parent path

entries.name: CHANGENAME
entries.description: Returns a new path with its name (last segment) changed

entries.name: CHANGEEXTENSION
entries.description: Returns a new path with extension changed

entries.name: ISPARENT
entries.description: True if path is the parent of this path

entries.name: COMBINE
entries.description: Returns a new path created by adding further elements to this one

entries.name: Volume
entries.description: Represents a kOSProcessor hard disk or the archive.

entries.name: FREESPACE
entries.description: Free space left on the volume

entries.name: CAPACITY
entries.description: Total space on the volume

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Get or set volume name

entries.name: RENAMEABLE
entries.description: True if the name can be changed

entries.name: ROOT
entries.description: Volume’s root directory

entries.name: FILES
entries.description: Lexicon of all files and directories on the volume

entries.name: POWERREQUIREMENT
entries.description: Amount of power consumed when this volume is set as the current volume

entries.name: EXISTS
entries.description: Returns true if the given file or directory exists

entries.name: CREATE
entries.description: Creates a file

entries.name: CREATEDIR
entries.description: Creates a directory

entries.name: OPEN
entries.description: Opens a file or directory

entries.name: DELETE
entries.description: Deletes a file or directory

entries.name: Volumedirectory
entries.description: Represents a directory on a kOS file system. Instances of this class are enumerable, every step of iteration will provide a VolumeFile or a VolumeDirectory contained in this directory.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF VOLUMEITEM
entries.description: VolumeDirectory objects are a type of VolumeItem

entries.name: LEXICON
entries.description: Lists all files and directories

entries.name: LEX
entries.description: Alias for LEXICON

entries.name: LIST
entries.description: Alias for LEXICON

entries.name: Volumefile
entries.description: File name and size information. You can obtain a list of values of type VolumeFile using the LIST FILES command.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF VOLUMEITEM
entries.description: VolumeFile objects are a type of VolumeItem

entries.name: READALL
entries.description: Reads file contents

entries.name: WRITE
entries.description: Writes the given string to the file

entries.name: WRITELN
entries.description: Writes the given string and a newline to the file

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: Clears this file

entries.name: Volumeitem
entries.description: Contains suffixes common to files and directories.

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Name of the item including extension

entries.name: EXTENSION
entries.description: Item extension

entries.name: SIZE
entries.description: Size of the file

entries.name: ISFILE
entries.description: Size of the file

entries.name: Aggregateresource
entries.description: A ship can have many parts that contain resources (i.e. fuel, electric charge, etc). kOS has several tools for getting the summation of each resource. This is the type returned as the elements of the list from LIST RESOURCES.
entries.snippet:
PRINT "THESE ARE ALL THE RESOURCES ON THE SHIP:".
LIST RESOURCES IN RESLIST.
FOR RES IN RESLIST {
    PRINT "Resource " + RES:NAME.
    PRINT "    value = " + RES:AMOUNT.
    PRINT "    which is "
          + ROUND(100*RES:AMOUNT/RES:CAPACITY)
          + "% full.".
}.

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Resource name

entries.name: AMOUNT
entries.description: Total amount remaining

entries.name: CAPACITY
entries.description: Total amount when full

entries.name: DENSITY
entries.description: Density of this resource

entries.name: PARTS
entries.description: Parts containing this resource

entries.name: Alt
entries.description: ALT is a special object that exists just to help you get the altitudes of interest for a vessel future. It is grandfathered in for the sake of backward compatibility, but this information is also available on the Vessel structure as well, which is the better new way to do it:

entries.name: APOAPSIS
entries.description: altitude in meters of SHIP’s apoapsis. Same as SHIP:APOAPSIS.

entries.name: PERIAPSIS
entries.description: altitude in meters of SHIP’s periapsis. Same as SHIP:PERIAPSIS.

entries.name: RADAR
entries.description: Altitude of SHIP above the ground terrain, rather than above sea level.

entries.name: Bounds
entries.description: kOS can return information about the “bounding box” around either a whole vessel, or a part on a vessel. When it does so, the structure it uses to tell your script about it is called a “Bounds”. You can obtain a Bounds one of two ways:

entries.name: ABSORIGIN
entries.description: origin point of box, in absolute ship-raw coords.

entries.name: FACING
entries.description: The orientation of the box’s own reference frame.

entries.name: RELMIN
entries.description: a corner of the box in box’s own reference frame.

entries.name: RELMAX
entries.description: opposite corner of the box from RELMIN, in box’s own reference frame.

entries.name: ABSMIN
entries.description: a corner of the box in absolute (ship-raw) reference frame.

entries.name: ABSMAX
entries.description: opposite corner of the box from RELMIN, in absolute (ship-raw) reference frame.

entries.name: ABSCENTER
entries.description: center of the box (not its origin), in absolute (ship-raw) frame.

entries.name: RELCENTER
entries.description: center of the box (not its origin), in box’s own reference frame.

entries.name: EXTENTS
entries.description: A vector from box center to max corner, in box’s reference frame.

entries.name: SIZE
entries.description: Exactly 2 times EXTENTS - the vector from min corner to max, in box’s reference frame.

entries.name: FURTHESTCORNER
entries.description: Position (in absolute ship-raw coords) of the box corner most “that-a-way”.

entries.name: BOTTOMALT
entries.description: Sea-level altitude of bottom-most corner of box.

entries.name: BOTTOMALTRADAR
entries.description: Radar altitude of bottom-most corner of box.

entries.name: RELORIGIN IS MISSING
entries.description: This suffix is deliberately missing because it would always be V(0,0,0).

entries.name: Consumedresource
entries.description: A single resource value an engine consumes (i.e. fuel, oxidizer, etc). This is the type returned by the Engine:CONSUMEDRESOURCES suffix

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Resource name

entries.name: AMOUNT
entries.description: Total amount remaining (only valid while engine is running)

entries.name: CAPACITY
entries.description: Total amount when full (only valid while engine is running)

entries.name: DENSITY
entries.description: Density of this resource

entries.name: FUELFLOW
entries.description: Current volumetric flow rate of fuel

entries.name: MAXFUELFLOW
entries.description: Untweaked maximum volumetric flow rate of fuel

entries.name: REQUIREDFLOW
entries.description: Required volumetric flow rate of fuel for current throttle

entries.name: MASSFLOW
entries.description: Current mass flow rate of fuel

entries.name: MAXMASSFLOW
entries.description: Untweaked maximum mass flow rate of fuel

entries.name: RATIO
entries.description: Volumetric flow ratio of this resource

entries.name: Consumedresourcercs
entries.description: A single resource value an rcs thruster consumes (i.e. monopropellant, etc). This is the type returned by the RCS:CONSUMEDRESOURCES suffix

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Resource name

entries.name: AMOUNT
entries.description: Total amount remaining (only valid while engine is running)

entries.name: CAPACITY
entries.description: Total amount when full (only valid while engine is running)

entries.name: DENSITY
entries.description: Density of this resource

entries.name: RATIO
entries.description: Volumetric flow ratio of this resource

entries.name: Core
entries.description: Core represents your ability to identify and interact directly with the running kOS processor. You can use it to access the parent vessel, or to perform operations on the processor’s part. You obtain a CORE structure by using the bound variable core.

entries.name: Crafttemplate
entries.description: The CRAFTTEMPLATE structure.

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: Name of this craft template

entries.name: FILEPATH
entries.description: The path to the craft file

entries.name: DESCRIPTION
entries.description: The description as saved in the editor

entries.name: EDITOR
entries.description: The editor where this craft was saved

entries.name: LAUNCHSITE
entries.description: The default launch site for this craft

entries.name: MASS
entries.description: The default mass of the craft

entries.name: COST
entries.description: The default cost of the craft

entries.name: PARTCOUNT
entries.description: The total number of parts in this craft.

entries.name: Crewmember
entries.description: Represents a single crew member of a vessel.

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: crew member’s name

entries.name: GENDER
entries.description: “Male” or “Female”

entries.name: EXPERIENCE
entries.description: experience level (number of stars)

entries.name: TRAIT
entries.description: “Pilot”, “Engineer” or “Scientist”

entries.name: TOURIST
entries.description: true if this crew member is a tourist

entries.name: PART
entries.description: part in which the crew member is located

entries.name: Decoupler
entries.description: Some of the Parts returned by LIST PARTS will be of type Decoupler. It is a type of Part, and therefore can use all the suffixes of Part. It serves as base for all decouplers, separators, launch clamps and docking ports. Most Decoupler parts are actually Separator parts, which is where most of the suffixes for them are found.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF PART
entries.description: A Decoupler is a kind of Part

entries.name: Deltav
entries.description: A DeltaV contains information about the delta-V numbers the stock KSP game calculates for you in the user interface (in the staging list display). There are in fact two different kinds of DeltaV structures in kOS - one that refers to the whole veseel, or one that refers to just one stage of the vessel. You can obtain a DeltaV about the sum of the whole vessel with SHIP:DELTAV. For example:
entries.snippet: PRINT "Vessel's total dV number is " + SHIP:DELTAV:CURRENT.

entries.name: CURRENT
entries.description: How much DeltaV (meters/second) at curent atmospheric conditions?

entries.name: ASL
entries.description: How much DeltaV (meters/second) at sea level conditions?

entries.name: VACUUM
entries.description: How much DeltaV (meters/second) at vacuum conditions?

entries.name: DURATION
entries.description: How many seconds at maxthrust will emit this deltaV?

entries.name: FORCECALC
entries.description: Call to force KSP to re-run its simulator to recalc deltaV.

entries.name: Dockingport
entries.description: Some of the Parts returned by LIST PARTS will be of type DockingPort. Such part can also be retrieved from TARGET, if docking port is selected as target.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF DECOUPLER
entries.description: A DockingPort is a kind of Decoupler (which is Part)

entries.name: ACQUIRERANGE
entries.description: active range of the port

entries.name: ACQUIREFORCE
entries.description: force experienced when docking

entries.name: ACQUIRETORQUE
entries.description: torque experienced when docking

entries.name: REENGAGEDDISTANCE
entries.description: distance at which the port is reset

entries.name: DOCKEDSHIPNAME
entries.description: name of vessel the port is docked to

entries.name: NODEPOSITION
entries.description: coords of where the docking node attachment point is in SHIP-RAW xyz

entries.name: NODETYPE
entries.description: two nodes are only dockable together if their NODETYPE strings match

entries.name: PORTFACING
entries.description: facing of the port

entries.name: STATE
entries.description: current state of the port

entries.name: UNDOCK
entries.description: callable to release the dock

entries.name: PARTNER
entries.description: the docking port this docking port is attached to, or “None” if no such port

entries.name: HASPARTNER
entries.description: whether or not this docking port is attached to another docking port

entries.name: TARGETABLE
entries.description: check if this port can be targeted

entries.name: Element
entries.description: An element is a docked component of a Vessel. When you dock several vessels together to create one larger vessel, you can obtain the “chunks” of the larger vessel organized by which original vessel they came from. These “chunks” are called elements, and they are what the Element structure refers to. A list of elements from the vessel can be created by using the command:
entries.snippet:
list elements in eList.
// now eList is a list of elements from the vessel.

entries.name: NAME
entries.description: The name of the docked craft

entries.name: UID
entries.description: Unique Identifier

entries.name: PARTS
entries.description: all Parts

entries.name: DOCKINGPORTS
entries.description: all DockingPorts

entries.name: VESSEL
entries.description: the parent Vessel

entries.name: RESOURCES
entries.description: all AggrgateResources

entries.name: Engine
entries.description: Some of the Parts returned by LIST PARTS will be of type Engine. It is also possible to get just the Engine parts by executing LIST ENGINES, for example:

entries.name: ACTIVATE
entries.description: Turn engine on

entries.name: SHUTDOWN
entries.description: Turn engine off

entries.name: THRUSTLIMIT
entries.description: Tweaked thrust limit

entries.name: MAXTHRUST
entries.description: Untweaked thrust limit. Zero if engine disabled.

entries.name: MAXTHRUSTAT
entries.description: Max thrust at the specified pressure (in standard Kerbin atmospheres). Zero if engine disabled.

entries.name: THRUST
entries.description: Current thrust. Zero if engine disabled.

entries.name: AVAILABLETHRUST
entries.description: Available thrust at full throttle accounting for thrust limiter. Zero if engine disabled.

entries.name: AVAILABLETHRUSTAT
entries.description: Available thrust at the specified pressure (in standard Kerbin atmospheres). Zero if engine disabled.

entries.name: POSSIBLETHRUST
entries.description: Possible thrust at full throttle accounting for thrust limiter, when the engine is enabled.

entries.name: POSSIBLETHRUSTAT
entries.description: Possible thrust at the specified pressure (in standard Kerbin atmospheres), when the engine is enabled.

entries.name: FUELFLOW
entries.description: Current volumetric flow rate of fuel.

entries.name: MAXFUELFLOW
entries.description: Untweaked maximum volumetric flow rate of fuel at full throttle.

entries.name: MASSFLOW
entries.description: Current mass flow rate of fuel.

entries.name: MAXMASSFLOW
entries.description: Untweaked maximum mass flow rate of fuel at full throttle.

entries.name: ISP
entries.description: Specific impulse

entries.name: ISPAT
entries.description: Specific impulse at the given pressure (in standard Kerbin atmospheres).

entries.name: VACUUMISP
entries.description: Vacuum specific impulse

entries.name: VISP
entries.description: Synonym for VACUUMISP

entries.name: SEALEVELISP
entries.description: Specific impulse at Kerbin sealevel

entries.name: SLISP
entries.description: Synonym for SEALEVELISP

entries.name: FLAMEOUT
entries.description: Check if no more fuel

entries.name: IGNITION
entries.description: Check if engine is active

entries.name: ALLOWRESTART
entries.description: Check if engine can be reactivated

entries.name: ALLOWSHUTDOWN
entries.description: Check if engine can be shutdown

entries.name: THROTTLELOCK
entries.description: Check if throttle can not be changed

entries.name: MULTIMODE
entries.description: Check if engine has multiple modes

entries.name: MODES
entries.description: List (string) of the engine modes

entries.name: MODE
entries.description: Name of the current mode (only if multiple)

entries.name: TOGGLEMODE
entries.description: Switch to another mode (only if multiple)

entries.name: PRIMARYMODE
entries.description: Is the engine in primary mode? (only if multiple)

entries.name: AUTOSWITCH
entries.description: Can the engine switch modes automatically? (only if multiple)

entries.name: HASGIMBAL
entries.description: Check if engine has gimbal

entries.name: GIMBAL
entries.description: Gimbal of this engine (only if available)

entries.name: ULLAGE
entries.description: Does this engine need ullage (for RealFuels)

entries.name: FUELSTABILITY
entries.description: How stable is the fuel for this engine (for RealFuels)

entries.name: PRESSUREFED
entries.description: Is this engine pressure fed? (for RealFuels)

entries.name: IGNITIONS
entries.description: Number of ignitions remaining for this engine (for RealFuels)

entries.name: MINTHROTTLE
entries.description: The minimum throttle setting for this engine (for RealFuels)

entries.name: CONFIG
entries.description: Engine configuration name (for RealFuels)

entries.name: CONSUMEDRESOURCES
entries.description: The fuel resources this engine consumes, and in what ratios

entries.name: Gimbal
entries.description: Many engines in KSP have thrust vectoring gimbals which are handled by their own module

entries.name: LOCK
entries.description: Is the Gimbal locked in neutral position?

entries.name: PITCH
entries.description: Does the Gimbal respond to pitch controls?

entries.name: YAW
entries.description: Does the Gimbal respond to yaw controls?

entries.name: ROLL
entries.description: Does the Gimbal respond to roll controls?

entries.name: LIMIT
entries.description: Percentage of the maximum range the Gimbal is allowed to travel

entries.name: RANGE
entries.description: The Gimbal’s Possible Range of movement

entries.name: RESPONSESPEED
entries.description: The Gimbal’s Possible Rate of travel

entries.name: PITCHANGLE
entries.description: Current Gimbal Pitch

entries.name: YAWANGLE
entries.description: Current Gimbal Yaw

entries.name: ROLLANGLE
entries.description: Current Gimbal Roll

entries.name: Kosprocessor
entries.description: The type of structures returned by kOS when querying a module that contains a kOS processor.

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF PARTMODULE
entries.description: kOSProcessor objects are a type of PartModule

entries.name: MODE
entries.description: OFF, READY or STARVED

entries.name: ACTIVATE
entries.description: Activates this processor

entries.name: DEACTIVATE
entries.description: Deactivates this processor

entries.name: TAG
entries.description: This processor’s name tag

entries.name: VOLUME
entries.description: This processor’s hard disk

entries.name: BOOTFILENAME
entries.description: The filename for the boot file on this processor

entries.name: CONNECTION
entries.description: Returns your connection to this processor

entries.name: Launchclamp
entries.description: LaunchClamp is there to help you identify launch clamps in parts and is of type Decoupler (which is Part).

entries.name: ALL SUFFIXES OF DECOUPLER
entries.description: A LaunchClamp is a kind of Decoupler (which is Part)

entries.name: Maneuver Node
entries.description: Contents

entries.name: DELTAV
entries.description: The burn vector with magnitude equal to delta-V

entries.name: BURNVECTOR
entries.description: Alias for DELTAV

entries.name: ETA
entries.description: Time until this maneuver

entries.name: TIME
entries.description: Universal Time of this maneuver

entries.name: PROGRADE
entries.description: Delta-V along prograde

entries.name: RADIALOUT
entries.description: Delta-V along radial to orbited Body

entries.name: NORMAL
entries.description: Delta-V along normal to the Vessel’s Orbit

entries.name: ORBIT

entries.name: Part

entries.name: Partmodule
entries.description: Almost everything done with at right-click menus and action group action can be accessed via the PartModule objects that are attached to Parts of a Vessel. The exact arrangement of PartModule to Parts to Vessels, and how to make use of a PartModule is a complex enough topic to warrant its own separate subject, described on the Ship parts and Modules page. If you have not read that page, it is recommended that you do so before using PartModules. The page you are reading now is meant as just a reference summary, not a tutorial.

entries.name: Connection
entries.description: Connections represent your ability to communicate with other processors or vessels. You can use them to find out whether such communication is currently possible and send messages.
entries.snippet:
SET MY_PROCESSOR TO PROCESSOR("second").
SET MY_CONNECTION TO MY_PROCESSOR:CONNECTION.

entries.name: ISCONNECTED
entries.description: true if this connection is currently opened

entries.name: DELAY
entries.description: delay in seconds

entries.name: DESTINATION
entries.description: destination of this connection

entries.name: SENDMESSAGE
entries.description: Sends a message using this connection

entries.name: Message
entries.description: Represents a single message stored in a CPU’s or vessel’s MessageQueue. The main message content that the sender intended to send can be retrieved using Message:CONTENT attribute. Other suffixes are automatically added to every message by kOS.

entries.name: SENTAT
entries.description: date this message was sent at

entries.name: RECEIVEDAT
entries.description: date this message was received at

entries.name: SENDER
entries.description: vessel which has sent this message, or Boolean false if sender vessel is now gone

entries.name: HASSENDER
entries.description: Tests whether or not the sender vessel still exists.

entries.name: CONTENT
entries.description: message content

entries.name: Messagequeue
entries.description: Just like ordinary queues message queues work according to First-In first-out principle. You can read more about queues on Wikipedia. Whenever you send a message to a CPU or a vessel it gets added to the end of that CPU’s or vessel’s message queue. The recipient can then read those messages from the queue.
entries.snippet:
SET QUEUE TO CORE:MESSAGES.
PRINT "Number of messages on the queue: " + QUEUE:LENGTH.

entries.name: EMPTY
entries.description: true if there are no messages in the queue

entries.name: LENGTH
entries.description: number of messages in the queue

entries.name: POP
entries.description: returns the oldest element in the queue and removes it

entries.name: PEEK
entries.description: returns the oldest element in the queue without removing it

entries.name: CLEAR
entries.description: remove all messages

entries.name: PUSH
entries.description: explicitly append a message

entries.name: Orbiteta
entries.description: OrbitEta is a special object that exists just to help you get the times from now to certain events in an orbit’s future. It operates on an Orbit, and can be obtained one of two ways:
entries.snippet:
print SHIP:OBT:ETA:APOAPSIS.
print SHIP:OBT:NEXTPATCH:ETA:APOAPSIS.

entries.name: Orbitable (Vessels And Bodies)
entries.description: All objects that can move in orbit around other objects share some similar structure. To help keep things as consistent as possible, that similar structure is defined here. Everything you see here works for both Vessels and Bodies.
entries.deprecationNote: Deprecated since version 0.15: This is only kept here for backward compatibility. in new scripts you write, use OBT:APOAPSIS. (i.e. use SHIP:OBT:APOAPSIS instead of SHIP:APOAPSIS, or use MUN:OBT:APOAPSIS instead of MUN:APOAPSIS, etc).

entries.name: Orbitablevelocity
entries.description: When any Orbitable object returns its VELOCITY suffix, it returns it as a structure containing a pair of both its orbit-frame velocity and its surface-frame velocity at the same instant of time. To obtain its velocity as a vector you must pick whether you want the oribtal or surface velocities by giving a further suffix:
entries.snippet:
SET VORB TO SHIP:VELOCITY:ORBIT
SET VSRF TO SHIP:VELOCITY:SURFACE
SET MUNORB TO MUN:VELOCITY:ORBIT
SET MUNSRF TO MUN:VELOCITY:SURFACE

entries.name: Colors
entries.description: Any place you need to specify a color in the game (at the moment this is just with VECDRAW, HIGHLIGHT. and HUDTEXT) You do so with a rgba color structure defined as follows: Method 1: Use one of these pre-arranged named colors:
entries.snippet: SET myColor TO RGB(r,g,b).

entries.name: :R OR :RED
entries.description: the red component of the color

entries.name: :G OR :GREEN
entries.description: the green component of the color

entries.name: :B OR :BLUE
entries.description: the blue component of the color

entries.name: :A OR :ALPHA
entries.description: the alpha (how opaque: 1 = opaque, 0 = transparent) component of the color

entries.name: :HTML OR :HEX
entries.description: the color rendered into a HTML tag string i.e. “#ff0000”. This format ignores the alpha channel and treats all colors as opaque.

entries.name: :H OR :HUE
entries.description: the hue component of the color. It is a value from 0.0 to 360.0

entries.name: :S OR :SATURATION
entries.description: the saturation component of the color. It has a value from 0.0 to 1.0

entries.name: :V OR :VALUE
entries.description: the value component of the color. It has a value from 0.0 to 1.0

entries.name: Note
entries.description: Notes are structures that get passed in to the SKID chip to tell it what tone to play and for how long. All the suffixes of a Note are read-only, and you’re only ever expected to set them by constructing a new Note using the built-in Note() function, or the built-in SlideNote() function:
entries.snippet:
SET V1 TO GETVOICE(0).
V1:PLAY( NOTE(440, 0.2, 0.25, 1) ).

entries.name: Pidloop
entries.description: A PID loop is a standard control mechanism taught in many control theory textbooks. It’s a simple way to deal with a scenario where you want a program to move a control lever of some sort in order to cause a measured phenomenon to settle on a target value. That base description actually covers many scenarios:
entries.snippet: SET MYPID TO PIDLOOP(Kp, Ki, Kd, min_output, max_output, epsilon).

entries.name: Time
entries.description: kOS provides two types you can use to work with game-time. One is the TimeStamp and the other is the TimeSpan. This page describes both, and the differences between them. Similarities between ``TimeStamp`` and ``TimeSpan``: Both TimeStamp and TimeSpan store an amount of time, and can show you that time divided up into years, days, hours, minutes, and seconds.
entries.snippet:
// Notice these are equal because year and day start at 1 not 0:
set t1 to TIMESTAMP(0).
set t2 to TIMESTAMP(1,1,0,0,0).
print t1:full.
print t2:full. // Prints same as above.

entries.name: Voice
entries.description: This structure represents a single one of the ‘voices’ in the built-in sound chip called SKID in the kOS CPU. Please refer to the SKID chip documentation page if you have not already done so before reading this page. The things mentioned here are just ways to access the features of the SKID chip so they won’t be fully explained on this page, instead just referring to the SKID documentation with links.
entries.snippet:
SET V0 to GetVoice(0).
V0:PLAY(NOTE(440,0.5)).

entries.name: F
entries.description: There is a bound variable called CONSTANT which contains some basic fundamental constants about the universe that you may find handy in your math operations. Prior to kOS version 0.18, CONSTANT was implemented as a function call, so values were accessed as CONSTANT():PI and the like. This functionality has been retained for backward compatibility, but new code should instead call CONSTANT:PI.

entries.name: T
entries.description: There are some consequences when converting from a Direction to a Vector and vice versa which should not be overlooked. Therefore if you do this: Then MyDir will be a Direction, but it will be a Direction where you have no control over which way is “up” for it.

entries.name: ABS
entries.description: Returns absolute value of input: PRINT ABS(-1). // prints 1
entries.snippet: PRINT ABS(-1). // prints 1

entries.name: CEILING
entries.description: Rounds up to the nearest whole number: PRINT CEILING(1.887). // prints 2
entries.snippet: PRINT CEILING(1.887). // prints 2

entries.name: FLOOR
entries.description: Rounds down to the nearest whole number: PRINT FLOOR(1.887). // prints 1
entries.snippet: PRINT FLOOR(1.887). // prints 1

entries.name: LN
entries.description: Gives the natural log of the provided number: PRINT LN(2). // prints 0.6931471805599453

entries.name: LOG10
entries.description: Gives the log base 10 of the provided number: PRINT LOG10(2). // prints 0.30102999566398114

entries.name: MOD
entries.description: Returns remainder from integer division. Keep in mind that it’s not a traditional mathematical Euclidean division where the result is always positive. The result has the same absolute value as mathematical modulo operation but the sign is the same as the sign of dividend: PRINT MOD(21,6). // prints 3 PRINT MOD(-21,6). // prints -3
entries.snippet:
PRINT MOD(21,6). // prints 3
PRINT MOD(-21,6). // prints -3

entries.name: MIN
entries.description: Returns The lower of the two values: PRINT MIN(0,100). // prints 0
entries.snippet: PRINT MIN(0,100). // prints 0

entries.name: MAX
entries.description: Returns The higher of the two values: PRINT MAX(0,100). // prints 100
entries.snippet: PRINT MAX(0,100). // prints 100

entries.name: RANDOM
entries.description: Returns the next random floating point number from a random number sequence. The result is always in the range [0..1] This uses what is called a pseudo-random number generator. For basic usage you can leave the key parameter off and it works fine, like so: Example, basic usage: PRINT RANDOM(). //prints a random number PRINT "Let's roll a 6-sided die 10 times:". FOR n in range(0,10) { // To make RANDOM give you an integer in the range [0..n-1], you do this: // floor(n*RANDOM()). // So for example

entries.name: RANDOMSEED
entries.description: No Return Value. Initializes a new random number sequence from a seed, giving it a key name you can use to refer to it in future calls to RANDOM(key) Using this you can make psuedo-random number sequences that can be re-run using the same seed to get the same result a second time. Parameter key is a string - a name you can use to refer to this random series later. Calls to RANDOMSEED that use different keys actually cause different new random number sequences to be created that are tracked separ
entries.snippet:
RANDOMSEED("generator A",1000).
RANDOMSEED("generator B",1000).
PRINT "Generators A and B should emit identical ".
PRINT "sequences because they both started at seed 1000.".
PRINT "3 numbers from Generator A:".
PRINT floor(RANDOM("generator A")*100).
PRINT floor(RANDOM("generator A")*100).
PRINT floor(RANDOM("generator A")*100).
PRINT "3 numbers from Generator B - they should ".
PRINT "be the same as above:".
PRINT floor(RANDOM("generator B")*100).
PRINT floor(RANDOM("generator B")*100).
PRINT f

entries.name: ROUND
entries.description: Rounds to the nearest whole number: PRINT ROUND(1.887). // prints 2
entries.snippet: PRINT ROUND(1.887). // prints 2

entries.name: SQRT
entries.description: Returns square root: PRINT SQRT(7.89). // prints 2.80891438103763

entries.name: CHAR
entries.description: Parameters a – (number) Returns (string) single-character string containing the unicode character specified PRINT CHAR(34) + "Apples" + CHAR(34). // prints "Apples"
entries.snippet: PRINT CHAR(34) + "Apples" + CHAR(34). // prints "Apples"

entries.name: UNCHAR
entries.description: Parameters a – (string) Returns (number) unicode number representing the character specified PRINT UNCHAR("A"). // prints 65
entries.snippet: PRINT UNCHAR("A"). // prints 65

entries.name: SIN
entries.description: Parameters a – (deg) angle Returns sine of the angle PRINT SIN(6). // prints 0.10452846326
entries.snippet: PRINT SIN(6). // prints 0.10452846326

entries.name: COS
entries.description: Parameters a – (deg) angle Returns cosine of the angle PRINT COS(6). // prints 0.99452189536
entries.snippet: PRINT COS(6). // prints 0.99452189536

entries.name: TAN
entries.description: Parameters a – (deg) angle Returns tangent of the angle PRINT TAN(6). // prints 0.10510423526
entries.snippet: PRINT TAN(6). // prints 0.10510423526

entries.name: ARCSIN
entries.description: Parameters x – (Scalar) Returns (deg) angle whose sine is x PRINT ARCSIN(0.67). // prints 42.0670648
entries.snippet: PRINT ARCSIN(0.67). // prints 42.0670648

entries.name: ARCCOS
entries.description: Parameters x – (Scalar) Returns (deg) angle whose cosine is x PRINT ARCCOS(0.67). // prints 47.9329352
entries.snippet: PRINT ARCCOS(0.67). // prints 47.9329352

entries.name: ARCTAN
entries.description: Parameters x – (Scalar) Returns (deg) angle whose tangent is x PRINT ARCTAN(0.67). // prints 33.8220852
entries.snippet: PRINT ARCTAN(0.67). // prints 33.8220852

entries.name: ARCTAN2
entries.description: Parameters y – (Scalar) x – (Scalar) Returns (deg) angle whose tangent is \(\frac{y}{x}\) PRINT ARCTAN2(0.67, 0.89). // prints 36.9727625 The two parameters resolve ambiguities when taking the arctangent. See the wikipedia page about atan2 for more details.
entries.snippet: PRINT ARCTAN2(0.67, 0.89). // prints 36.9727625

entries.name: S
entries.description: Scalar numbers are allowed to be represented in any number of ways, both in the source code and in strings passed in to the String:TOSCALAR method. Underscores are allowed as visual spacers provided you don’t lead with an underscore. The purpose of the underscores is to group numbers apart, similar to how some cultures use a comma in numbers like ‘1,234,567’ (and others use a dot). There is no enforcement of rules for where you can and cannot put the underscores for grouping. kerboscript just strips them out and ignores them anyway: One decimal point is allowed to show fractional parts, but you must lead with a digit, even it’s just to say “0.”: You may use scientific notation (with an ‘e’ and an optional sign, and a string of digits) to shift the decimal place:

entries.name: O
entries.description: You can use math operations on Direction objects as well. The next example uses a rotation of “UP” which is a system variable describing a vector directly away from the celestial body you are under the influence of: Supported Direction Operators: For vector operations, you may use the :VECTOR suffix in combination with the regular vector methods:

entries.name: L
entries.description: The implementation of Scalars can currently only store values that fit the following criteria:

entries.name: C
entries.description: Converting between SHIP-RAW and SOI-RAW reference frames is a simple matter of moving the origin point by adding or subtracting the SHIP:BODY:POSITION vector from the coordinate. This works because both frames are using the same axes rotation.

entries.name: V
entries.description: Parameters x – (scalar) \(x\) coordinate y – (scalar) \(y\) coordinate z – (scalar) \(z\) coordinate Returns Vector This creates a new vector from 3 components in \((x,y,z)\): SET vec TO V(x,y,z). Here, a new Vector called vec is created . The object Vector represents a three-dimensional euclidean vector To deeply understand most vectors in kOS, you have to understand a bit about the underlying coordinate system of KSP. If you are having trouble making sense of the direction the axes point in, g
entries.snippet: SET vec TO V(x,y,z).

entries.name: VDOT
entries.description: Same as VECTORDOTPRODUCT(v1,v2) and v1 * v2.

entries.name: VECTORDOTPRODUCT
entries.description: Parameters v1 – (Vector) v2 – (Vector) Returns The vector dot-product Return type Scalar This is the dot product of two vectors returning a scalar number. This is the same as v1 * v2: SET vec1 TO V(1,2,3). SET vec2 TO V(2,3,4). // These are different ways to perform the same operation. // All of them will print the value: 20 // ------------------------------------------------------- PRINT VDOT(vec1, vec2). PRINT VECTORDOTPRODUCT(vec1, vec2). PRINT vec1 * vec2. // multiplication of two vectors wi

entries.name: VCRS
entries.description: Same as VECTORCROSSPRODUCT(v1,v2)

entries.name: VECTORCROSSPRODUCT
entries.description: Parameters v1 – (Vector) v2 – (Vector) Returns The vector cross-product Return type Vector The vector cross product of two vectors in the order (v1,v2) returning a new Vector: SET vec1 TO V(1,2,3). SET vec2 TO V(2,3,4). // These will both print: V(-1,2,-1) PRINT VCRS(vec1, vec2). PRINT VECTORCROSSPRODUCT(vec1, vec2). When visualizing the direction that a vector cross product will point, remember that KSP is using a left-handed coordinate system, and this means a cross-product of two vectors will
entries.snippet:
SET vec1 TO V(1,2,3).
SET vec2 TO V(2,3,4).

// These will both print: V(-1,2,-1)
PRINT VCRS(vec1, vec2).
PRINT VECTORCROSSPRODUCT(vec1, vec2).

entries.name: VANG
entries.description: Same as VECTORANGLE(v1,v2).

entries.name: VECTORANGLE
entries.description: Parameters v1 – (Vector) v2 – (Vector) Returns Angle between two vectors Return type Scalar This returns the angle between v1 and v2. It is the same result as: \[\arccos\left( \frac{ \vec{v_1}\cdot\vec{v_2} }{ \left|\vec{v_1}\right|\cdot\left|\vec{v_2}\right| } \right)\] or in KerboScript: arccos( (VDOT(v1,v2) / (v1:MAG * v2:MAG) ) )
entries.snippet: arccos( (VDOT(v1,v2) / (v1:MAG * v2:MAG) ) )

entries.name: VXCL
entries.description: Same as VECTOREXCLUDE(v1,v2)

entries.name: VECTOREXCLUDE
entries.description: This is a vector, v2 with all of v1 excluded from it. In other words, the projection of v2 onto the plane that is normal to v1.

entries.name: R
entries.description: A Direction can be created out of a Euler Rotation, indicated with the R() function, as shown below where the pitch, yaw and roll values are in degrees: SET myDir TO R( a, b, c ).
entries.snippet: SET myDir TO R( a, b, c ).

entries.name: Q
entries.description: A Direction can also be created out of a Quaternion tuple, indicated with the Q() function, passing it the x, y, z, w values of the Quaternion. The concept of a Quaternion uses complex numbers and is beyond the scope of the kOS documentation, which is meant to be simple to understand. It is best to not use the Q() function unless Quaternions are something you already understand. SET myDir TO Q( x, y, z, w ).
entries.snippet: SET myDir TO Q( x, y, z, w ).

entries.name: HEADING
entries.description: A Direction can be created out of a HEADING() function. The first parameter is the compass heading, and the second parameter is the pitch above the horizon: SET myDir TO HEADING(degreesFromNorth, pitchAboveHorizon). The third parameter, roll, is optional. Roll indicates rotation about the longitudinal axis.
entries.snippet: SET myDir TO HEADING(degreesFromNorth, pitchAboveHorizon).

entries.name: LOOKDIRUP
entries.description: A Direction can be created with the LOOKDIRUP function by using two vectors. This is like converting a vector to a direction directly, except that it also provides roll information, which a single vector lacks. lookAt is a vector describing the Direction’s FORE orientation (its local Z axis), and lookUp is a vector describing the direction’s TOP orientation (its local Y axis). Note that lookAt and lookUp need not actually be perpendicualr to each other - they just need to be non-parallel in some

entries.name: ANGLEAXIS
entries.description: A Direction can be created with the ANGLEAXIS function. It represents a rotation of degrees around an axis of axisVector. To know which way a positive or negative number of degrees rotates, remember this is a left-handed coordinate system: // Pick a new rotation that is pitched 30 degrees from the current one, taking into account // the ship's current orientation to decide which direction is the 'pitch' rotation: // SET pitchUp30 to ANGLEAXIS(-30,SHIP:STARFACING). SET newDir to pitchUp30*SHIP:FA

entries.name: ROTATEFROMTO
entries.description: A Direction can be created with the ROTATEFROMTO function. It is one of the infinite number of rotations that could rotate vector fromVec to become vector toVec (or at least pointing in the same direction as toVec, since fromVec and toVec need not be the same magnitude). Note the use of the phrase “infinite number of”. Because there’s no guarantee about the roll information, there are an infinite number of rotations that could qualify as getting you from one vector to another, because there’s an
entries.snippet: SET myDir to ROTATEFROMTO( v1, v2 ).

entries.name: LATLNG
entries.description: Parameters lat – (deg) Latitude lng – (deg) Longitude Returns GeoCoordinates This function creates a GeoCoordinates object with the given latitude and longitude, assuming the current SHIP’s Body is the body to make it for. Once created it can’t be changed. The GeoCoordinates:LAT and GeoCoordinates:LNG suffixes are get-only (they cannot be set.) To switch to a new location, make a new call to LATLNG(). If you wish to create a GeoCoordinates object for a latitude and longitude around a different b
entries.snippet: SET spot to SHIP:GEOPOSITION.

entries.name: FUNCTION
entries.description: There exist a number of built-in functions you can call using their names. When you do so, you can do it like so: For example, the ROUND function takes 2 arguments: The SIN function takes 1 argument: When a function requires zero arguments, it is legal to call it using the parentheses or not using them. You can pick either way:

entries.name: BREAK
entries.description: Breaks out of a loop:

entries.name: IF
entries.description: Checks if the expression supplied returns true. If it does, IF executes the following command block. Can also have an optional ELSE to execute when the IF condition is not true. ELSE can have another IF after it, to make a chain of IF/ELSE conditions:

entries.name: CHOOSE
entries.description: An expression that evalualtes to one of two choices depending on a conditional check: Note this is NOT a statement. This is an expression that can be embedded inside other statements, like so: The reason to use the CHOOSE operator instead of an IF/ELSE statement is that IF/ELSE won’t return a value, while this does, and thus this can be embedded inside other expressions. (This is similar to the ? operator in languages like “C” and its derivatives, except it puts the “true” choice first, then the

entries.name: LOCK
entries.signature: Locks an identifier to an expression.
entries.description: Locks an identifier to an expression. Each time the identifier is used in an expression, its value will be re-calculated on the fly: LOCK follows the same scoping rules as the SET command. If the variable name used already exists in local scope, then the lock command creates a lock function that only lasts as long as the current scope and then becomes unreachable after that. If the variable name used does not exist in local scope, then LOCK will create it as a global variable, unless @LAZYGLOBAL

entries.name: UNLOCK
entries.description: Releases a lock on a variable. See LOCK:

entries.name: UNTIL
entries.description: Performs a loop until a certain condition is met: Note that if you are creating a loop in which you are watching a physical value that you expect to change each iteration, it’s vital that you insert a small WAIT at the bottom of the loop like so: The full explanation why is in the CPU hardware description page.

entries.name: FOR
entries.description: Loops over a list collection, letting you access one element at a time. Syntax: Where: Example:

entries.name: FROM
entries.description: Identical to the UNTIL loop, except that it also contains an explicit initializer and incrementer section in the header.

entries.name: WAIT
entries.description: Halts execution for a specified amount of time, or until a specific set of criteria are met. Note that running a WAIT UNTIL statement can hang the machine forever if the criteria are never met. Examples: Note that any WAIT statement, no matter what the actual expression is, will always result in a wait time that lasts at least one physics tick.

entries.name: DECLARE
entries.description: In kerboscript, you can make your own user functions using the DECLARE FUNCTION command, which has syntax as follows: The statement is called a “declare function” statement even when the optional word “declare” was left off. Example:

entries.name: RETURN
entries.description: Covered in more depth elsewhere in the documentation, the RETURN statement causes a user function, or a trigger body, to end, and chooses what the calling part of the program will see if it reads the value of the function.

entries.name: WHEN
entries.signature: WHEN / THEN statements, and ON statements
entries.description: The WHEN and the ON statement are very similar to each other, and so they are documented together here. WHEN and ON both begin checking in the background for a condition that will cause some code to execute some statements later on. They do NOT cause the code to necessarily get run right now. The check will occur at regular fast intervals in the background, and the code will trigger whenever kOS next notices that the check happens to be true. kOS has a feature known as a trigger, and a WHEN or a

entries.name: PRESERVE
entries.signature: PRESERVE is a command keyword that is only valid inside of WHEN/THEN and ON code blocks.
entries.description: PRESERVE is a command keyword that is only valid inside of WHEN/THEN and ON code blocks. When a WHEN/THEN or ON condition is triggered, the default behavior is to execute the code block body exactly once and only once, and then the trigger condition is removed and the trigger will never occur again. To alter this, a new ability was added in kOS 0.19.3 and above to have triggers simply return a true or false value to determine if they wish to be preserved. But prior to kOS 0.19.3, the only way to

entries.name: SET
entries.signature: Sets the value of a variable.
entries.description: Sets the value of a variable. Implicitly creates a global variable if it doesn’t already exist, unless the @lazyglobal off directive has been given: This follows the scoping rules explained below. If the variable can be found in the current local scope, or any scope higher up, then it won’t be created and instead the existing one will be used. It is also possible to set the values of multiple variables in a single SET statement by separating the assignments with commas, as shown below:

entries.name: LOCAL
entries.description: You can explicitly make a LOCK statement be LOCAL with the LOCAL keyword, like so: LOCAL LOCK identifier TO expression. But be aware that doing so with a cooked steering control such as THROTTLE or STEERING will not actually affect your ship. The automated cooked steering control is only reading the GLOBAL locks for these settings. The purpose of making a LOCAL lock is if you only need to use the value temporarily for the duration of a function call, loop, or if-statement body, and then you don’

entries.name: ON
entries.description: Sets a variable to TRUE. This is useful for the RCS and SAS bindings: This follows the same rules as SET, in that if the variable in question doesn’t already exist, it will end up creating it as a global variable.

entries.name: TO
entries.description: Toggles a variable between TRUE or FALSE. If the variable in question starts out as a number, it will be converted to a boolean and then toggled. This is useful for setting action groups, which are activated whenever their values are inverted: This follows the same rules as SET, in that if the variable in question doesn’t already exist, it will end up creating it as a global variable.

entries.name: SAS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Turns the SAS on or off, like using T at the keybaord: SAS ON. // same as SET SAS TO TRUE. SAS OFF. // same as SET SAS TO FALSE. PRINT SAS. // prints either "True" or "False". Warning Be aware that having KSP’s SAS turned on will conflict with using “cooked control” (the lock steering command). You should not use these two modes of steering control at the same time. For further information see the warning in lock steering documentation.
entries.snippet:
SAS ON. // same as SET SAS TO TRUE.
SAS OFF. // same as SET SAS TO FALSE.
PRINT SAS.  // prints either "True" or "False".

entries.name: LIGHTS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Turns the lights on or off, like using the U key at the keyboard: LIGHTS ON.
entries.snippet: LIGHTS ON.

entries.name: BRAKES
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Turns the brakes on or off, like clicking the brakes button, though not like using the B key, because they stay on: BRAKES ON.
entries.snippet: BRAKES ON.

entries.name: GEAR
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Deploys or retracts the landing gear, like using the G key at the keyboard: GEAR ON.
entries.snippet: GEAR ON.

entries.name: ABORT
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Abort action group (no actions are automatically assigned, configurable in the editor), like using the Backspace key at the keyboard: ABORT ON.
entries.snippet: ABORT ON.

entries.name: AG1
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean 10 custom action groups (no actions are automatically assigned, configurable in the editor), like using the numeric keys at the keyboard: AG1 ON. AG4 OFF. SET AG10 to AG3.
entries.snippet:
AG1 ON.
AG4 OFF.
SET AG10 to AG3.

entries.name: LEGS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Deploys or retracts all the landing legs (but not wheeled landing gear): LEGS ON. Returns true if all the legs are deployed.
entries.snippet: LEGS ON.

entries.name: CHUTES
entries.description: Access Toggle ON; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Deploys all the parachutes (only ON command has effect): CHUTES ON. Returns true if all the chutes are deployed.
entries.snippet: CHUTES ON.

entries.name: PANELS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Extends or retracts all the deployable solar panels: PANELS ON. Returns true if all the panels are extended, including those inside of fairings or cargo bays. Note Some solar panels can’t be retracted once deployed. Consult the part’s description for details.
entries.snippet: PANELS ON.

entries.name: RADIATORS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Extends or retracts all the deployable radiators and activates or deactivates all the fixed ones: RADIATORS ON. Returns true if all the radiators are extended (if deployable) and active.
entries.snippet: RADIATORS ON.

entries.name: LADDERS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Extends or retracts all the extendable ladders: LADDERS ON. Returns true if all the ladders are extended.
entries.snippet: LADDERS ON.

entries.name: BAYS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Opens or closes all the payload and service bays (including the cargo ramp): BAYS ON. Returns true if at least one bay is open.
entries.snippet: BAYS ON.

entries.name: DEPLOYDRILLS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Deploys or retracts all the mining drills: DEPLOYDRILLS ON. Returns true if all the drills are deployed.
entries.snippet: DEPLOYDRILLS ON.

entries.name: DRILLS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Activates (has effect only on drills that are deployed and in contact with minable surface) or stops all the mining drills: DRILLS ON. Returns true if at least one drill is actually mining.
entries.snippet: DRILLS ON.

entries.name: FUELCELLS
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Activates or deactivates all the fuel cells (distingushed from other conveters by converter/action names): FUELCELLS ON. Returns true if at least one fuel cell is activated.
entries.snippet: FUELCELLS ON.

entries.name: ISRU
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Activates or deactivates all the ISRU converters (distingushed from other conveters by converter/action names): ISRU ON. Returns true if at least one ISRU converter is activated.
entries.snippet: ISRU ON.

entries.name: INTAKES
entries.description: Access Toggle ON/OFF; get/set Type Action Group, Boolean Opens or closes all the air intakes: INTAKES ON. Returns true if all the intakes are open.
entries.snippet: INTAKES ON.

entries.name: SWITCH
entries.description: Changes the current directory to the root directory of the specified volume. Volumes can be referenced by instances of Volume, their ID numbers or their names if they’ve been given one. Understanding how volumes work is important to understanding this command. Example:

entries.name: LOG
entries.description: Logs the selected text to a file. Can print strings, or the result of an expression.

entries.name: EDIT
entries.description: Arguments: Edits or creates a program file described by filename PATH. If the file referred to by PATH already exists, then it will open that file in the built-in editor. If the file referred to by PATH does not already exist, then this command will create it from scratch and let you start editing it. It is important to type the command using the filename’s .ks extension when using this command to create a new file. (Don’t omit it like you sometimes can in other places in kOS). The logic to auto

entries.name: CLEARSCREEN
entries.description: Clears the screen and places the cursor at the top left: CLEARSCREEN.
entries.snippet: CLEARSCREEN.

entries.name: PRINT
entries.description: Prints the selected text to the screen. Can print strings, or the result of an expression: PRINT "Hello". PRINT 4+1. PRINT "4 times 8 is: " + (4*8).
entries.snippet:
PRINT "Hello".
PRINT 4+1.
PRINT "4 times 8 is: " + (4*8).

entries.name: REBOOT
entries.description: Stops the script here, and reboots the kOS module.

entries.name: SHUTDOWN
entries.description: Stops the script here, and causes kOS module to turn the power off.

entries.name: PROGRADE
entries.description: A direction pointing along the vessel's orbital velocity.

entries.name: NORMAL
entries.description: A direction pointing perpendicular to the orbit plane.

entries.name: TARGET
entries.description: The current target vessel or body.

entries.name: MUN
entries.description: The Mun, Kerbin's first moon.

entries.name: EVE
entries.description: The planet Eve.

entries.name: SUN
entries.description: The star Kerbol (the Sun).

entries.name: SHIP
entries.description: Reference to the vessel running the script.

entries.name: RETROGRADE
entries.description: A direction pointing opposite to the vessel's orbital velocity. Used for deceleration burns.
entries.snippet: LOCK STEERING TO RETROGRADE.

entries.name: ANTINORMAL
entries.description: A direction pointing opposite to normal, perpendicular to the orbit plane.

entries.name: RADIAL
entries.description: A direction pointing away from the body being orbited (radially outward).

entries.name: ANTIRADIAL
entries.description: A direction pointing toward the body being orbited (radially inward).

entries.name: SRFPROGRADE
entries.description: Surface prograde - the direction of travel relative to the surface.

entries.name: SRFRETROGRADE
entries.description: Surface retrograde - opposite to the direction of travel relative to the surface.

entries.name: VECTOR
entries.description: A 3D vector with X, Y, Z components. Used for positions, velocities, and directions. Create with V(x,y,z) function.
entries.snippet:
SET myVec TO V(1, 2, 3).
PRINT myVec:MAG. // magnitude

entries.name: THROTTLE
entries.description: A special variable that controls the vessel's throttle. Lock it to a value between 0.0 (no thrust) and 1.0 (full thrust).
entries.snippet:
LOCK THROTTLE TO 1.0.
WAIT UNTIL SHIP:APOAPSIS > 80000.
LOCK THROTTLE TO 0.

entries.name: STEERING
entries.description: A special variable that controls the vessel's attitude. Lock it to a direction to have the autopilot point the ship.
entries.snippet:
LOCK STEERING TO PROGRADE.
WAIT 5.
LOCK STEERING TO HEADING(90, 45).
